section.title: Testing libCellML
section.paragraph: Every pull request against the libCellML prime repository is tested as a matter of course, but there might be times when youâ€™d like to test your own code without making a pull request. There are two ways you can do this.

section.title: Using the Buildbot site
section.paragraph: Buildbot has the capacity to build a libCellML compliant repository through the use of a ForceScheduler . To make use of this facility, you will need to authenticate with the Buildbot system. Access granted on request to David Nickerson d.nickerson@auckland.ac.nz. The website http://www.htaccesstools.com/htpasswd-generator/ can be used if you do not have access to the htpasswd application. When your request has been dealt with, you will be able to login to libCellML Buildbot and submit code for testing.

section.title: Manually on your local computer
section.paragraph: When your libCellML has built successfully, and with tests included, executables for the tests will be located in the build/test directory where your library has been built.

definition_list_item.term: Unit tests Run all of the unit tests using make test.

list_item.paragraph: Individual C++ unit tests may be run by locating the test executable within the tests/, directory. Unit tests for a given class are named test_classname, where classname is the lowercase name of the class to test. These files are executable, so can be run from the command line tests/test_classname.

To run individual Python tests, navigate first into the tests/bindings/python/ directory. The test files can then be run individually as needed using python test_classname.py, where classname is the lowercase name of the class to test.

Coverage tests Coverage tests make sure that each line of code is covered by one or more unit tests. - A summary of coverage of the C++ code is accessible through make llvm_coverage, which result in statistics of line coverage. - For detailed information regarding specific lines in each file that need test coverage, use the command TODO.
